message.content: We refer to an anatomy atlas for help. The symptoms, specifically the location of pain and tingling in the thumb, index, and middle fingers, along with the observation of atrophy of the thenar eminence, suggest carpal tunnel syndrome. The nerve affected is the median nerve, which is represented by option (C) in the image provided.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical exam suggest carpal tunnel syndrome, which affects the median nerve, depicted as nerve D in the image provided. The atrophy of the thenar eminence is a hallmark feature of this syndrome, and the pain is reproduced with wrist flexion. Option A is the ulnar nerve, which can be affected in cubital tunnel syndrome; option B is the radial nerve, which can be affected in radial tunnel syndrome; option E is the musculocutaneous nerve, which can be affected in nerve compression or injury in the upper arm.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest carpal tunnel syndrome, which affects the median nerve shown in option D. However, option D is not listed, but option C shows the median nerve and its path towards the wrist, which is consistent with the symptoms described. Atrophy of the thenar eminence also indicates involvement of the median nerve.

We refer to a neuroanatomy textbook for help. The symptoms and physical exam findings suggest carpal tunnel syndrome, which affects the median nerve (nerve shown in option C) as it passes through the carpal tunnel in the wrist. The thenar eminence is innervated by the median nerve, which explains the atrophy observed. The symptoms located in the thumb, index, and middle fingers are consistent with median nerve distribution.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of pain and tingling in the thumb, index, and middle fingers, as well as atrophy of the thenar eminence, suggest carpal tunnel syndrome. This condition affects the median nerve, which is represented by nerve (C) in the provided image.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of symptoms, physical examination findings, and location of pain suggest carpal tunnel syndrome, which affects the median nerve (shown in option C). Atrophy of the thenar eminence is a key physical finding in diagnosing carpal tunnel syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of symptoms and physical exam findings suggest carpal tunnel syndrome, which affects the median nerve (shown as D in the image). Atrophy of the thenar eminence and pain during wrist flexion are common findings in carpal tunnel syndrome.

We refer to the image provided and Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The image shows the pathway of the median nerve, which innervates the thumb, index, and middle fingers. Atrophy of the thenar eminence and pain reproduced with wrist flexion are signs of carpal tunnel syndrome, which is caused by compression of the median nerve at the wrist. Therefore, the correct answer is (C).

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical exam findings suggest carpal tunnel syndrome, which involves the median nerve (nerve shown in option C) being compressed at the wrist. The atrophy of thenar eminence is a specific sign for carpal tunnel syndrome. Options A, B, and E are not involved in carpal tunnel syndrome.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical exam findings are consistent with carpal tunnel syndrome, which affects the median nerve shown in option D. Option C is the correct answer, which is the median nerve. Options A, B, and E are other nerves in the hand but not directly involved in carpal tunnel syndrome.
